bibl.title: Letter from John H. Andrus to Philip Showalter Hench, April 26, 1941

div1.p: Andrus writes that some of the enlisted men thought it highly unlikely that Lazear would have allowed a stray mosquito to bite him. It was known that Carroll was inoculated by mosquito-bite, but not clear if that was the cause of Carroll's disease as he also had been in the epidemic zone. He looks forward to Hench's comments on his manuscript.

div1.head: Letter from John H. Andrus to Philip Showalter Hench, April 26, 1941
div1.opener:
J. H. Andrus
805 Cooper St.
Camden, N. J.
4-26-41
Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
I want you to know how very much I appreciate your kindness
in coming to see me yesterday. Now that we have met I
shall value your friendship more than ever...

Yesterday I made a statement with reference to Dr. Lazear's
innoculation that was, upon reflection, entirely too broad.
I told you that it was the “general belief” that Dr. Lazear
had innoculated himself intentionally. I blush to confess
that I had no means of knowing what the general belief was.
All I actually know is that a few of the enlisted men of the
Hospital Corps detachment - the only ones I heard on the sub-
ject - thought it highly improbable that Dr. Lazear would
allow a casual mosquitoes to bite him in view of his belief that
yellow fever was transmitted by mosquito-bite.

At the time of Dr. Lazear's death he was known to have innoc-
ulated Dr. Carroll by mosquito-bite but it was not definitely
known that the innoculation was the cause of Dr. Carroll's
getting the disease. He had been in the epidemic zone.
Dean's innoculation by Dr. Lazear was not known, generally,
at that time. Dean was innoculated without military author-
ity and the facts kept under cover until long afterward.

Hospital Steward John Neate - with whom I worked in Major
Reed's laboratory - believed Dr. Lazear had innoculated him-
self. I never heard the insurance angle until I read it
in General Truby's manuscript...

Am looking forward to your comments on my “story” with a great
deal of interest. I hope you will take your gloves off and
be perfectly frank. I have no illusions about my abilities
as a writer so the only way you could possibly surprise me
would be to be complimentary. Compliments would not help
while complete candor might enable me to rewrite the story to
make it acceptable.

If Mr. Kellogg does not change his mind about getting Mr. Corn-
wall to go to bat for me, I have renewed hope that one of the
Hearst publications may use it. Even so, I would want to
re-write it in accordance with your suggestions.

I realize that I am asking a lot. This should make you more
careful in the future about just which dumb animals you are
kind to.
